results.title: Emulation of Bazooka Bill for Spectrum 48/128
results.brief_description:
Bazooka Bill is a single player side scrolling shoot ‘em up action plaformer. Bill fights his way through side scrolling maps of different islands to rescue General MacArthur. Bill begins with only his fists and can collect additional weaponry throughout his journey.

Original game developed by Melbourne House for Spectrum 48/128, Published in 1985 by Melbourne House

results.title: Emulation of Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum ZX 48k
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

production_dates.notes: Harvested from World of Spectrum (https://worldofspectrum.org/archive/software/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron-melbourne-house) 3/8/2015 by volunteer Caroline Choong as part of ARC Play It Again project.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Vitaphone Disc: Columbia Pictures Corporation, "Wall Street", CP- B37 Reel Six, Times Played 1
results.brief_description: Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. Vitaphone was the last major analog sound-on-disc system and the only one which was widely used and commercially successful.

results.title: Freedom rides
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers”.
Charles Perkins grew up in Alice Springs in a time when racial segregation was the rule. Sent away to Adelaide for an education he became increasingly aware of the injustices perpetrated against Australian First Nations peoples. In 1965 he instigated the “Freedom ride” - a busload of concerned people, mostly students - who visited outback Australia, notably Walgett and Moree, to escalate the level of public awareness of racial intolerance in Australia. This video documents that journey and talks to those who took part.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures

results.title: Jardiwarnpa: a Warlpiri fire ceremony
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins, City Pictures, Warlpiri Media and Warlukurlangu Artists
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
In order to combat the influence of western culture the elders of the Warlpiri people, led by Darby Jampijinpa Ross, a noted Aboriginal artist, decided to perform a fire ceremony which tells the story of Yarripiri’s journey. Yarripiri is both a real person and an incarnation of a dreamtime spirit. This video documents the preparations for the ceremony, the ceremony itself, the story the ceremony recreates and the problems the people have in performing it. Narrated by Kev Carmody.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins, City Pictures, Warlpiri Media and Warlukurlangu Artists

results.title: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Interspersed with video clips from his protest album “Pillars of society” Kev Carmody talks about his life and music. Born in Goronba, Queensland, on a cattle station, the son of an Irish stockman and his Aboriginal wife, Carmody spent his early years living off the land, but absorbing western culture through the ABC and old records. Taken away from his parents at the age of ten, he was put in a Christian school and sent home twice a year. After several years working at various menial jobs, whilst developing his music he eventually gained a Ph.D in Australian history, using oral material and methods rather than a written thesis. A fascinating portrait of a committed man.
results.title_for_label: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer
